Michigan Ongoing Health & Safety Training Refresher 2023
Section 4: Handling & Storage of Hazardous Materials & Appropriate Disposal of Bio-contaminants 

What are some common toxins?

All child care sites have the potential for having unknown environmental toxins.  Select each flashcard to read more about some common environmental toxins. 

Lead

Lead can be found in soil, paint chips, toys, and water impacted by pipes made of lead or copper. Lead has a significant impact on the nervous system. Even at lower levels of exposure, it can reduce a childâ€™s IQ, lessen their attention span, and cause learning disabilities, hyperactivity, and behavioral difficulties. It can also lead to long standing health problems.

Mercury

Mercury can be found in old thermometers and thermostats, batteries, and fluorescent light bulbs. It is important to keep these items out of the reach of children.

Radon

Radon is an odorless gas that can affect health and development. It is recommended that all child care centers test for radon. Family and Group Child Care Homes are required per LARA to test for radon when an original license is issued and every four years at renewal. If elevated radon levels are found, mitigation should be done.

Carbon Monoxide

Carbon Monoxide is a deadly, colorless, odorless, poisonous gas. Young children are especially vulnerable to the effects of carbon monoxide because of their small bodies. It is produced by the incomplete burning of various fuels. Using a carbon monoxide detector is the only way to identify whether it is at a dangerous level.
